title: Ash frontman delight with Girl From Mars mural
story: ASH frontman Tim Wheeler was back in his home town of Downpatrick last week to see work completed on a huge muralpaying homage to one of the bandrsquos biggest hits mdash Girl From Mars.The mural mdash which is certainly a lsquoshining lightrsquo at this part of the town mdash has been painted on a gable wall at the entrance to the Church Street car park by artist Marian Noone and her husband Gerry Norman.The mural is part of a pound, revitalisation scheme which is being financed by Newry, Mourne and Down Council and the Department for Communities.Tim was impressed with the stunning art work which is part of the drive to revitalise a part of Downpatrick which has missed out on major public sector investment over recent years.Girl From Mars was written by the Downpatrick musician when he was  in  with the song going on to become Ashrsquos breakthrough hit.Girl From Mars remains the bandrsquos defining moment with the  hit still a firm favourite today.Tim has previously revealed that he wrote the song at his parentrsquos home, most probably after coming home from Down High School.ldquoI saw in a TV listing that there was a film on, called Girl From Mars, and seeing that title sparked my imagination, he said.ldquoWhen yoursquore forming your identity as a teenager, yoursquore always grabbing little snippets of everything and it all went into the song. Irsquod just broken up with my first girlfriend and I think it was me subconsciously expressing stuff about that.Confirming the sci-fi influence, Tim mdash who recently became a dad for the first time mdash said Girl From Mars mostly revolves around the verse and chorus.ldquoI wrote them as a slow little strummy thing and then when we worked on it as a band we rocked it out quite a lot. My little brother Pat was always my first port of call of seeinga song was good and then Irsquod bring it to [bandmates] Mark [Hamilton] and Rick [McMurray].ldquoI used to love going and knocking on his bedroom door and playing him ideas and I remember that he flipped out about the song and loved it. He had the idea for the quiet verse after the guitar solo and it was great.Tim said as soon as the band started playing it they got a really good reaction from their friends.ldquoI used to play stuff before Irsquod even fully written the lyrics wersquod play stuff at shows and Irsquod mumble my way through it. I donrsquot think I wrote the second verse until we actually recorded it two years later.ldquoI wasnrsquot too worried about lyrics back then, maybe because I listened to Nirvana so much and could never really understand them. Our manager and the record label were sure it was going to be a hit, so we put it aside until wersquod be able to promote it. We put it out as a single two weeks after leaving school and it just blew up.Meanwhile, as part of the Church Street investment plan in Downpatrick, around pound, has been earmarked for a shop front improvement scheme with the emphasis on painting and repairing existing facades.Elsewhere, it is proposed to spend pound, on what is being described as a ldquoconcept design of Church Street with the work due to be carried out by a consultant, with pound, earmarked for improving shop fronts in Bridge Street.Fteen thousand pounds has been earmarked for De Courcey Place in English Street to replace a number of heritage-style lamps and signposts, alongside the provision of new litter bins and planting out existing granite water troughs.Just over pound, is to be spent on other planting and landscaping schemes in the Church Street area, while there are also proposals for a new bus stop and power washing the area outside the former telephone exchange, with new safety railings installed outside  Church Street.There are also plans to invest pound, on new interpretation material highlighting the Tower Bell at Down Parish Church and the grave of United Irishman Thomas Russell in the church grounds.Last Christmas, new festive lighting was provided on the side of the Down Arts Centre and on trees in De Courcey Place.Downpatrick area councillor Dermot Curran has praised everyone involved with the work in Church Street, in particular, the talented artists responsible for the murals.ldquoCongratulations to everyone involved in the project designed to breath new le into this part of the town. Given the fact that it has missed out on major funding over many years, the pound, investment initiative is particularly welcome, he said.ldquoThe money will help property owners revitalise their respective businesses at a key part of the town where there are a number of family-owned businesses..prettyPhoto

title: Ballynagross make it past Castlewellan
story: BALLYNAGROSS progressed to the final of the Harry Clarke Cup after defeating Castlewellan Forest by way of penalty shoot-out at Ballyhornan on Friday night.Ballynagross arrived at the match looking for a fourth Harry Clarke final in a row, but Castlewellan Forest had momentum following a close win against Ardglass in the quarter-final.Ballynagross got off to the best start they could have hoped for after a great attack from their defence through the field found Philip Doran, who easily finished to put his side one up in the first seven minutes.Castlewellan stepped it up a gear when a throw-in close to the box found Aidan Dornan, who headed just wide.Castlewellan had an appeal for hand ball ruled out closely after in the Ballynagross box, with the referee having none of it.Ballynagross responded to the pressure from Castlewellan with a pass from Philip Doran to Shea McComiskey out on the right wing. McComiskey saw team-mate Joseph Burns in the mouth of the goal and looped the ball in, but Burnsrsquo effort goes just wide.Castlewellan had their first real chance on the th minute when their corner-kick met the head of Donagh Steele. However, the ball went just over the bar.Ballynagross got their second goal on the th minute after a throw-in from Ryan Tumelty to John Shields allowed the attacker to spray a pass to the right wing to find team-mate Doran. The lively lsquoGross forward found Joseph Burns and the chance was duly converted into a goal.With half-time nearing, it looked like Ballynagross would be going into the interval with a comfortable lead, but an error when clearing the ball from the defence enabled Castlewellanrsquos David Gilmore to close the lead to just a goal as the referee blew his whistle.Castlewellan came out in the second-half with an all out attack approach and it paid off through a corner kick in the st minute.This time Donagh Steele ensured the ball was going into the back of the net and the game was level. It was not to stay this way for long as the Castlewellan goalkeeper clearly took Ballynagrossrsquo Shea McComiskey down inside the box and a penalty was awarded.Connor Marron stepped up to take the penalty and finished well into the top left corner of the net.Castlewellan continued to push forward, but Ballynagross defence of Corey Davis, Connor Marron, Ryan Tumelty and Tom McNeill were holding strong.For the next  minutes it was pretty even, Castlewellanrsquos Sean Dornan took a chance on the edge of the box but Cathail Arnold easily saved. Castlewellan were awarded a free-kick close to the Ballynagross net, but David Gilmorersquos effort was straight at the goalkeeper.Ballynagross had a chance from a corner but it was well cleared by Castlewellan.Forest striker Shane Mooney found himself booked for his comments to the referee in the rd minute.Castlewellan were very much seeking out a goal to level and it came in the th minute after a scrap for the ball in Ballynagrossrsquo box resulted in Shane Mooney scoring with the last kick of the game to send the tie to extra-time.There were a few chances during extra-time for Ballynagross, although neither team could find a break through to escape the need for penalties. Castlewellan swapped out Brian McVeigh in goal for Sean Dornan.Ballynagrossrsquo Connor Marron, who had already scored a penalty during the game, was first to step up and easily converted.Castlewellanrsquos Shane Mooney and Ballynagrossrsquo Declan Dowie followed and both scored.Forestrsquos new lsquokeeper Dornan came out of the net and rushed his penalty, sending the ball over the bar.John Mahoney made no mistake to give his lsquoGross side a further advantage before Ciaran Stratton kept Castlewellan in with a chance.Ballynagrossrsquo John Shields walked up to take his penalty but the lsquokeeper saved to bring it level again.Eoin Travers converted his penalty and now it was sudden death.Tom McNeill confidentially scored his penalty meaning all of the pressure fell on Castlewellanrsquos Ryan Morgan to keep the game going.However, his effort was saved resulting in Ballynagross progressing to the final.Ballynagross: C Arnold, T McNeill, R Tumelty, C Marron, C Davis, J Polley, J Shields, J Burns, L Shields, P Doran, S McComiskeySubs: D Craig, D Dowie, J Mahoney, K Taggart, A Beattie.Castlewellan Forest: B McVeigh, C McCabe, C Stratton, C Burns, J OrsquoNeill, N Travers, S Dornan, D Steele, S Mooney, A Dornan, D Gilmore Subs: S Kinley, G Kidd, E Travers, R Morgan, J Murnin..prettyPhoto

title: Dismal end to league campaign
story: DOWN senior footballersrsquo miserable campaign reached its conclusion as they lost out on home soil to Clare on Sunday.The Mourne side entered this fixture already relegated from Division  and were hoping to gain some,any, momentum ahead of their crucial upcoming Ulster campaign.The uphill task will include having to better Monaghan on May  and then the winner of Cavan and Antrim to make the concluding stage to feature in the All-Ireland series and avoid ato the second-tier championship.Down took to the field in Newry against a Clare side who had endured a mixed bag of results within their league fixtures having won their opening three before losing the next trio of matches.For Down, the loss concludes a point-starved run of fixtures having finished with just one draw and six losses.Clare fielded what appeared to be a physically stronger outfit than their counterparts at Paacuteirc Esler and Downrsquos efforts werenrsquot aided by their lack of discipline.Both Gerard Collins and Pat Havern picked up black cards towards the end of each half while team-mate Finn McElroy picked up a red card with  minutes played.By that stage, the Mourne side didnrsquot appear to be getting anything from the game but that will be little solace to Down boss James McCartan, who has endured a nightmare beginning to his second stint at the helm.Aaron Grfin scored the first goal of the match with nine minutes played, courtesy of a smart left-footed finish which bested Kilcoo-native Niall Kane at his near post.To their credit, Down showed some resilience and managed to notch the next four from five points available with Burren man Liam Kerr kicking over a well-taken score amongst these.However, Clare continued to attack the Down goal and found their second major of the match thanks to Cian OrsquoDearsquos effort.His lowly struck shot took the wind out of Downrsquos sails and the Mourne side entered the break six points adrt at - to -.There was a shining light for Down when substitute Corey Quinn entered the fray and caused some problems for the Clare defence, registering a personal tally of -.He was also unfortunate not to grab another but the most visible dference in the teams was the scoring outlets provided, with the visiting side registering points from  dferent players in contrast to Downrsquos six.Aside from this, it was a day to forget for the men in the red and black, who will require a much better performance next time they pull on the jersey.Down: N KaneA Lynch, F McElroy, T McInerney G Collins, C Poland, A Morgan R McEvoy, P HavernR OrsquoHiggins, L Kerr , C Doherty A Gilmore , B OrsquoHagan , J McCartan.Subs: C Quinnfor McCartan , C OrsquoRawe for OrsquoHiggins , K McKernan for McEvoy .Clare: S Ryan Conor Jordan, Ciaran Russell , Gavin CooneyJamie Malone, Cian OrsquoDea , Eoghan Collins Daniel Walsh, Darren OrsquoNeillPearse Lillis , Eoin Cleary , Emmet McMahonAaron Grfin , Keelan Sexton, David Tubridy Subs: B Rouinefor McMahon , B McNamara for Cooney , D McDonagh for Walsh , C Downes for Collins , J McGannfor Grfin ..prettyPhoto

title: DUP MLAs running again in Strangford
story: ITrsquoS case of as you were for the DUP which has confirmed that its three sitting candidates in the Strangford constituency will be contesting the May Assembly election.Crossgarrsquos Harry Harvey, former teacher Michelle McIlveen and Peter Weir will be aiming to retain their seats when voters go to the polls in just a few weeksrsquo time.Elected to Newry, Mourne and Down Council in , Mr Harvey is following in the political footsteps of his father Cecil and has represented the Strangford constituency as an MLA since  when he was co-opted to replace Simon Hamilton.In the Assembly, Mr Harvey has sat on the public accounts, education and agriculture committees, and helped shape key pieces of legislation.A committed Christian, he is a strong voice for traditional family values. He is also a well-known vintage car enthusiast and is involved with ious charity events.Ms McIlveen mdash who is Stormontrsquos education minister and lives in Ballygowan mdash has been a Strangford MLA since  and operates operates a full time constituency service in Comber with surgeries across Strangford.She is also been in charge of the agriculture and regional development portfolios at Stormont and during her role as education minister, brought forward legislation which allows lsquoyoung foryear childrenrsquo to defer when they start school, invested an initial poundm to address the causes of educational underachievement among working class Protestant boys and introduced compulsory CPR training.When in charge of regional development, Ms McIlveen established a coastal erosion forum to provide solutions for under threat coastal communities and advanced numerous road safety schemes around Strangford.Mr Weir has been an MLA for almost a quarter of a century and operates a full-time Newtownards constituency office, with surgeries in Scrabo, Westwinds, Ballywalter and Ballyhalbert.When he was education minister, he delivered signicant additional funding for schools, Surestart, Pathways, increased nurture unit provision and secured childrenrsquosto school following the coronavirus lockdown.In addition, he initiated a UK-first holiday free school meal payments and delivered Fair Start initiative tackling educational underachievement.As chairman of the Assemblyrsquos All Party Animal Welfare Group, Mr Weir secured the toughest animal cruelty regime in UK and has also progressed local educational, health, business, policing, community, infrastructure and roadsafety issues throughout Strangford.Each of the Strangford candidate say they are campaigning under the DUPrsquos five point plan for a better Northern Ireland with the focus on fixing the NHS, growing the economy, maintaining world class schools, removing the NorthernIreland Protocol and helping working families..prettyPhoto

title: Exciting developments for Ballykinlar project
story: DOWN GAArsquoS Ballykinlar project advisory board held a meeting on Monday and confirmed the use of the lucrative facility will be open to all.The exciting planned development includes four full-sized pitches ndash three of which will be floodlit ndash including a walking trail and multi-use games area as well as a two storey facility with changing rooms.This is with the aim to improve the quality of pitches available during evening hours across all sports in the district.Despite its many successes, Down GAA currently has no physical headquarters but rather relies on the goodwill of clubs and hire of schools   university facilities, mainly in both the Co Down and Co Armagh areas, to undertake training and development sessions with respect to county teams.Following a consultation process an agreement to lease was agreed by Down GAA in respect of  acres of land from the Ministry of Defence in ..prettyPhoto

title: Family fundraising in memory of Marc
story: A CHEQUE for almost pound, has been presented to the Air Ambulance Northern Ireland in memory of Castlewellan teenager Marc Quinn who died earlier this year.Marc, who was a member of Aughlisnafin GAC, died as a result of an accident on January  shortly after celebrating his th birthday.Friends of his family, including Michelle Bell who is a friend of Marcrsquos mother Jenny, chose to run in the Jimmyrsquos Ten eventin Downpatrick on March  in his memory and decided to donate the funds to Air Ambulance NI.Specially designed Aughlisnafin jerseys have also been created in Marcrsquos memory with a percentage of cost of the top also being donated to the charity.Marcrsquos parents, Garry and Jennie, and brothers Ruairiacute and Ryan, want to thank all those who have supported them over this very traumatic and dficult time, particularly Jennyrsquos sister, Anita Grant who has been a constant throughout.Marcrsquos family also want to express their gratitude to everyone who made a donation in their sonrsquos memory..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C  April 1%2C 1992
story: STRANGFORD ndash The Government is poised to unveil an astonishing pound million scheme to replace the Strangford ferry service with a road tunnel under the lough.The scheme has already been approved at ministerial level and it is believed that the pound million originally intended for the Downpatrick bypass road will be used as start-up capital, with phase top-up grants being sought from the European Community and the Ireland Fund as the scheme progresses.Plans for the mile-long road tunnel have been drawn up by senior consultants engaged by the government and it is believed that the entry points will be manned toll booth terminals in Strangford and Portaferry.The move to replace the ferry service with a tunnel received an extra impetus recently when it was revealed that the ferry service was running at a substantial loss and villagers in Strangford vetoed plans for a new jetty for the vessels.Sources within the government say that the tunnel plan, which has been gathering dust for a number of years, has now been reactivated and local roads bosses intend erting the money intended for Downpatrickrsquos ring road to the scheme before the end of the financial year.Publicly, however, officials are remaining tight-lipped about the project. ldquoThe tunnel plan was first put forward several years ago, but as far as I am aware there are no plans to revive it, said a press office spokesperson.Nevertheless, conservation organisations have been consulted about the possible environmental impact of a tunnel, and a study of its possible effects has been carried out by a university team under the guidance of Prof A Lilo.Prof Lilo told the Recorder: ldquoAs far as I can see, there would be little threat to the loughrsquos balanced ecosystem from a tunnel.There may, however, be an unsightly visual impact created by the large tunnel entrances needed in Strangford and Portaferry.CASTLEWELLAN ndash A new school is to be constructed on the site of the existing St Malachyrsquos High School in Castlewellan, it has been revealed this week.South Down MP Mr Eddie McGrady said he has been informed of the commitment of the Department of Education to a new school in the town.ldquoAn investment appraisal has recently been carried out by the Department of Education to consider how best to meet the long-term needs of the pupils at St Malachyrsquos and this has come out in favour of a new school on the existing site, he added.Mr McGrady said this week: ldquoI welcome this development as I have been making on-going representations on the matter to Lord Belstead and his predecessor as Education Minister, Dr Brian Mawhinney.ldquoThe school definitely requires additional accommodation and I am keen that is is provided on the existing site, he added.DOWNPATRICK ndash Teenagers, some as young as , are taking part in open-air drinking parties at secluded parts of Downpatrick it was revealed this week.The youth are paying adults to buy drink for them and then going to quiet parts of the town for their parties, a special meeting was told on Tuesday.The police have raided a number of these gatherings in recent months but the teenagers simply move to a dferent location and continue their drinking sprees.While the problem of underage drinking in Downpatrick has not risen in recent years it is nevertheless sufficiently worrying to prompt a group of local community representatives to get together to discuss ways of tackling the issue.Last week youth workers, headmasters, teachers, publicans and councillors met together under the auspices of the RUCrsquos Community Relations Branch and debated the causes and possible remedies of underage drinking.The end result of the discussion was that public awareness needs to be heightened, while teenagers, and their parents, should be appraised of the dangers of alcohol abuse in the young.Superintendent Ronnie Hawthorne, Downpatrick sub-isional commander explained that the problem is a province-wide concern and is not just confined to Downpatrick.He added that underage drinking is also taking place in other parts of Down District.ldquoThere is a problem throughout Northern Ireland and we cannot stop underage drinkers ourselves, we need the help of the whole community, said Superintendent Hawthorne.ldquoThere are a lot associated problems with underage drinking and we will talk to every interested body in a bid to cope with this matter, he added.The full extend of the problems were highlighted by the youth leader in charge of the Patrician Youth Centre, Siobhan Byrne, who has compiled a report on underway drinking which is to be presented to Down Council.KILLYLEAGH ndash The town of Killyleagh is set for a financial boost to help revive its economic, commercial and environmental appearance, it has been revealed.A preliminary application has been made to the International Fund for a core project to help trigger a revival in the townrsquos fortunes.And by the end of the year, plans to designate the town as a conservation area will be completed.The investment in Killyleaghrsquos future was revealed when the chairman of Down District Council, Mr Sean Quinn, officially launched proposals for the regeneration of the town.A special exhibition in the townrsquos library also features a display on the proposed conservation area for Killyleagh.Mr Quinn referred to community-led initiatives in Seeconnell and Strangford, and stressed the importance of a community coming together to take full advantage of the funding which is available to help themselves.The South Down MP, Mr Eddie McGrady, told the launch gathering that he has been delighted to assist the committee towards its goals of reviving the town.Mr McGrady said Killyleagh had recognised that it was very much an era of self-help.He looked forward to the day when Killyleagh is selected as the site for the Strangford Lough Liaison Office and is designated as the Gateway to Strangford Lough, fulfilling its tourist potential.LEITRIM ndash An  month battle to have a Leitrim footpath declared a right of way has found its way to Westminster.The Parliamentary Commissioner for Complaints has been asked to investigate Banbridge Councilrsquos handling of the matter after more than  people signed a petition asking for the adoption of the footpath as a right-of-way.The footpath, which is marked on ordnance survey maps dating from , sketches from the town lands of Slievenisky and Backaderry, through Carrivmoragh mountain and descends towards Leitrim by Heronrsquos Road.Local people claim that the path is very old and was once used to reach a Mass Rock on the Backaderry Mountain and in later times, to give a short-cut to the new church in Leitrim.It is also believed the footpath is part of the old highway system that existed before the road system was introduced, and links into a system of lanes that go to Ballynahinch.The Council first became involved in the matter in August  when the petition was formally presented, and shortly afterwards the council voted overwhelmingly to adopt the pathway, subject to legal opinions.However, for the next  months no progress was made on the matter until the council appointed a countryside officer in August . He prepared a report on the footpath, which came before the council earlier this month when it was decided not to adopt itAfterwards a statement from some of the local people seeking the right-of-way said the footpath passes over land belonging to  dferent families and only one has an objection to the council adopting it..prettyPhoto

title: Good Morning Down co
story: THE head of one of the districtrsquos leading charities is officially stepping down from her role next month.Linda Baker has been Good Morning Downrsquos co-ordinator for the past  years and has watched the organisation mdash which provides a telephone befriending service to elderly and vulnerable people across the district mdash increases its operation considerably.The charity provides a valuable leline service to many people across the district, with its hardworking volunteers in regular contact with those who feel vulnerable or at risk, making telephone calls to members at an agreed time each morning.Linda said the service was especially important during the height of the coronavirus pandemic with the deadly virus unfortunately curtailing get-togethers that were organised for clients.Working in partnership with the districtrsquos Policing and Community Safety Partnership, the South Eastern Trust and the Housing Executive, the charity has also received invaluable support from the Allen Lane Foundation and and Halax Community Foundation.ldquoWhen I joined Good Morning Down there were four volunteers making calls to around  people. Since then, the organisation has grown and the level of support we provided has widened considerably, Linda revealed.ldquoWe now have a team of  volunteers who are in contact with  people across the district. Despite the global pandemic, we continued to deliver the service from our homes with the calls even more appreciated by clients who could not go out themselves.Linda said that during the pandemic, the volunteers made an additional  calls to people, such was the need of elderly and vulnerable people across the community.ldquoWe started off calling people for a little friendly chat but the service we provided started to evolve. While chatting with clients remains at the heart of what we do to support those who are isolated, we now find ourselves helping people with a range of complex needs.ldquoThe charityrsquos work has evolved and I suppose it will continue to in the future, but Good Morningrsquos Down core principle will always remain the same.Linda paid tribute to all the charityrsquos staff and those who have supported the organisation over many years.ldquoWe are like family and I will be sorry to leave, she said. ldquoI have spent a large part of my working le with Good Morning Down and have literally lived and breathed the organisation and have been assisted by great people.Linda said it was ldquotremendous to meet clients when the charity organised its get-togethers and while these were put on hold due to the pandemic, she hopes there may be an opportunity do something before the end of the year.ldquoThat of course will be guided by the public health situation at the time as we are mindful that our clients are elderly, with a number of them also vulnerable.Linda said the charityrsquos service has never been more important and while she is leaving the organisation, she knows it will continue to be a key part of peoplersquos lives.She added: ldquoI really enjoyed my time with Good Morning Down and worked alongside really great people. They were the friendly voice at the end of the telephone who helped make a dference to peoplersquos lives.ldquoFor many, their chat with our volunteers was the only interaction they would have with others during the day and we were always conscious of that. We worked to make a dference and you build a special relationship with clients which is why it was so wonderful to see them when we all did meet up.As Linda prepares to say her final goodbyes, Good Morning Down is looking for someone to replace her at the helm of the charity.Anyone keen to take on taking on her role or interested in getting involved in the work of Good Morning Down is asked to contact her on    or email lindabakergmd@yahoo..prettyPhoto

title: History project looks back at  Jewish family’s links to Shrigley
story: THE remarkable contribution of Jewish families in saving Shrigley has been recalled in a unique history project.The story of how Jews, fleeing the Holocaust and Hitlers murderous purge in Europe, started arriving in the village just before the start of the Second World War and helped transform the fortunes of villagers after the Hungry Thirties is largely forgotten.But more than  years later, Shrigleys legacy is featuring in an on-line interactive map telling the stories of Jewish families who have left a lasting impact on Northern Ireland.Steven Jaffe has been researching the heritage of the Jewish community across Northern Ireland.ldquoThe goal of the Belfast Jewish Heritage project Shared History fund is to locate, preserve, document and make publicly available material relating to the Jewish community in Northern Ireland, said Mr Jaffe.ldquoIt shows  sites across Northern Ireland, including Shrigley, Saintfield and Downpatrick. We were delighted to learn from Chris Hagan of theimpact of the Jewish community in Shrigley and include it in our overall project.ldquoPeople can click on the location to learn more about the Jewish story connected to the site. Some of the sites are fairly obvious mdash like former synagogues in Belfast mdash but others mdash like Shrigley mdash will come as a surprise to many, even in the Jewish community.ldquoThanks to the work of Chris and others the remarkable contribution made by the Utitz family and fellow refugees to the people of Shrigley will not be forgotten.Led by the Utitz and Weiniger families, they set up United Chrome Tanners, a highly successful leather tannery, and a series of associated businesses.Among the names recorded are the Utitz brothers, Alfred and Jacob, and their son Erik.Other refugees connected with the business were Walter Weiniger from Austria, who opened Marybag factories in Killyleagh and Belfast which finished handbags, and the first managing director of United Chrome Tanners, Mr Horenovsky.The Jewish families were welcomed with open arms in Shrigley. Villagers had suffered from the awful impact of the Hungry Thirties in one of the most socially deprived regions of the UK after the closure of the village spinning mill in .By November  United Chrome Tanners were employing  people tanning sheep skins and cattle hides for shoes, handbags and clothing.Within less than  years they were a world leader, employing more than  people and under the leadership of Erik Utitz became the first NI winners of the Queens award for exports.Leather tanning eventually died out in the village in .Details of the Jewish project, which received funding from the National Lottery Heritage Fund, can be found at this website: www.belfastjewishheritage.org..prettyPhoto

title: Lawyer eyeing SDLP result in Strangford
story: CONOR Houston is hoping to become Strangfordrsquos first SDLP Assemblyman when voters go to the polls on May .A lawyer and civic activist, he is going head-to-head against the DUP, UUP and Alliance who currently hold the constituencyrsquos five seats and as the parties ramp up their respective election campaigns, Mr Houston has outlined why he decided to put his name forward.He said he has been very fortunate to have had a lot of great opportunities throughout his career and wants to bring the experiences he has to make a positive impact on the people in Strangford.Mr Houston said while he has never been in politics before, there have been a few moments in his career that he believes shaped him for political le.ldquoAs a lawyer, I fought against unfairness and injustice, he continued. ldquoOne of the most frustrating things was seeing young people end up in the criminal justice system.ldquoSo many of them came from situations of poverty, abuse, addiction and been failed by our education and care systems. Creating opportunity for our young people is the best way of ensuring that people have a real chance in le and donrsquot end in the criminal justice system.Mr Houston said that representing dozens of young men who got caught up in riots at the time of the lsquoflag protestsrsquo in  was especially dficult.ldquoThose who had planned, organised and, in many instances, stirred up the situation on the ground were never in the dock. Whilst those involved in rioting deserved to be held to account by our courts, this made me realise that we had much work to do to ensure we created better pathways for our young people and addressed some of the major challenges in our society, especially poverty and sectarianism.Mr Houston also outlined why hersquos now involved in supporting projects that create opportunities for young people.ldquoI was proud to lead a bid to bring the lsquoOne Young Worldrsquo forum for young leaders to Northern Ireland in , he said.ldquoThe event is the worldrsquos largest youth summit and will bring , young leaders from every country in the world to Northern Ireland next year. Hundreds of local young people will be able to get involved.Mr Houston said that his experience of running his own consulting business means that he has seen the challenges too many businesses face in terms of Brexit and political uncertainty.He added: ldquoBusiness is about finding solutions and working with others to get things done. These are important skills that I want to bring to Stormont. I hope the people here will give me a chance to work hard and deliver for them on May ..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle AC runners star in sunshine at Gullion race
story: SATURDAY saw the Slieve Gullion race hosted by Armagh AC ing to the calendar after an absence last year.Falling in the short category of approximately four miles but with still at least ft of climbing, it is a good warm up for the upcoming Hill and Dale series and there is usually a healthy number of Newcastle ACrsquos red and yellow vests attending.Starting on the narrow Ballard Road outside Lislea, the  racing made their way along the undulating sheep track for the first mile.Gullion is known for usually being soft underfoot and plenty of mud to contend with, but with the recent great spell of dry weather, the runners made light work of the track towards a few steeper outcrops to the first checkpoint of the north cairn.From there it was a straightforward path past Calliagh Beararsquos Lough towards checkpoint two on the summit south cairnand the high point of County Armagh.This was the two mile marker and from here the race gathered pace as this was the turn back towards the start, sharpening up after checkpoint one doubled up as checkpoint three.Davy Hicks continued his great form coming in under two minutes behind winner Andrew Tees of BARF to finish fth .JP Gartland was another top ten finisher, a minute after, in ninth place .Colm Murtagh was back on the hills and had a solid morningrsquos work to place th . Next in two minutes later, making good time on descent, was Pearse Brogan in th .A fantastic performance from junior Ciara Savage in thput her on the ladies podium in third.Sam McNeilly was then fourth lady home just behind Ciara in thand Stevie Rice followed Sam for the finish coming th place .One minute later Owen Brady, with another good effort, came in nd positionwhilst Seamus White was to take st place with a good time of .Thanks to Armagh AC for hosting and holding on a perfect day of conditions for the race.The first four men listed above gathered enough points to take third menrsquos team home on the day behind the host club and nearby Newry AC.The next NIMRA event is the classic Mourne Seven Sevens race on Saturday, April  where eight Newcastle runnerswill take on an elite field coming from across the water, including the likes of multiple Ben Nevis winner, Finlay Wild, amongst others..prettyPhoto

title: People urged to remain vigilant after latest blaze
story: APPEALS have been issued for people to act responsibly following a spate of devastating wildfires in the Mournes last week which destroyed huge swathes of land.The fires came almost a year after over  acres of rich habitat in the Mournes were ravaged by a catastrophic fire that was started maliciously and took firefighters several days to put out.The most recent fires have prompted a number of leading agencies to ask people to remain vigilant and reduce the risk of wildfires which pose a risk to le and property and cause extensive environmental damage.There is also concern that the fires in the Mournes are erting emergency services resources away from where they are most needed to protect the community.Wildfires broke out near the Silent Valley, near the Bloody Bridge and in the Glasdrumman area with the Fire and Rescue Service warning that its response to the incidents places an additional strain on its resources, appealing to the public to support the organisation by not starting fires in the countryside.The organisationrsquos Group Commander, Mark Smyth, said with the dry weather set to continue, it is asking the public to support firefighters by not starting fires in the countryside.He added: ldquoDealing with wildfires unnecessarily draws our resources away from where they are needed most ndash protecting our community. They also cause signicant damage to wildle and the environment.Mourne Heritage Trust staff helped with the response to last weekrsquos wildfires using strimmers to create fire breaks, also helping with a controlled back burn and using its argocat all-terrain vehicle and fogging unit to extinguish one branch of a fire that was threatening some field boundaries.In addition, one of the Trustrsquos teams, along with a firefighter, used this specialist equipment to extinguish the fire at Finlieve near Rostrevor.NI Water has also warned that wildfires can have impact on drinking water supplies.The organisation controls so-called water catchment areas in the Mournes which supply water to all of Northern Ireland. The organisation said while it is working hard to deal with the problem of wildfires, it wants to assure customers that tap water quality is unaffected and is of a very high quality.But NI Water has warned that wildfires within catchments not only pose a terrible risk to all le but can remove the primary layer of vegetation, leaving the burned bare soil exposed to erosion which then makes its way into the reservoirs, from where water is abstracted for treatment to provide drinking water.ldquoThe erosion caused by wildfire increases carbon and other polluting chemicals signicantly in untreated water, with sediment accumulating in streams, lakes and reservoirs, said NI Waterrsquos Rebecca Allen.ldquoThis makes raw water especially dficult and more expensive to treat at our facilities to the stringent standards required by the Drinking Water Regulations. A signicant amount of other work by our water supply colleagues also has to be undertaken at the treatment works to ensure excellent quality drinking water during these times.Rebecca added: ldquoExtra water samples have to be collected and analysed, streams from burned areas need isolated, and other remedial measures must be taken like blocking streams to protect reservoirs.Mournes councillor Willie Clarke has praised firefighters, other arms of the emergency services and the Mourne Heritage Trust for their efforts to bring the blaze at the Bloody Bridge under control.He said firefighters in particular were overwhelmed by the support from the community.ldquoI witnessed the devastation of the wildfire first hand which impacted a site that is a protected habitat renowned around the world, said Cllr Clarke.ldquoThe emergency services, particularly local fire crews, should be commended for the professionalism they displayed when dealing with these incidents. However, malicious fires place a massive strain on very limited resources and as we approach the summer I would urge people to be vigilant and report any suspicious activity to the PSNI.Cllr Clarke said the damage caused by gorse fires has a lasting impact and that areas of outstanding natural beauty can take years to recover, calling for a co-ordinated response from the Department for Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs, NI Water, health and public safety departments and the Department of Justice.He continued: ldquoWe need to see a collective response with a sharing of resources and there needs to be additional funding provided to build upon the best practice Mourne Heritage Trust has undertaken to reduce the impact of these fires in the High Mournes. Controlled burns and better land-management needs to be re-established.ldquoMeasures should include the establishment of fire breaks to reduce the fuel load and a cross-departmental strategic response to ensure that the scale of these fires should never happen again.Cllr Clarke said it is important that police proactively investigate what are environmental crimes and those responsible need to be assured that these types of crime will not be tolerated in society.South Down MLA Sinead Ennis has also praised firefighters for their efforts in battling huge fires in the Mournes which started at Hen Mountain and Spelga Dam.She added: ldquoTragically, these fires will have caused widespread damage to the environment and our wildle. This is yet another stark reminder that everyone must behave responsibly while visiting the Mournes in order to protect the environment and the safety of the local community..prettyPhoto

title: Reality TV star Matthew visits ex primary school
story: FRESH from Dancing With The Stars Ireland, TV star Matthew MacNabb and his new girlfriend took the chance to visit his former primary school last week.Matthew and his professional dance partner, Laura Nolan, visited St Patrickrsquos Primary School, Legamaddy, after making it to the semi-final of the top RTE show.The visit to the school, which the Downpatrickrsquos manrsquos brother and sisters also attended, coincided with the school celebrating news of receiving a sizeable grant.It has been awarded pound, which will go towards creating a pollinator garden in the school grounds.Pupils were delighted to show Matthew and Laura around the school, particularly its new outdoor learning hub which allows to have an outdoor classroom for eco projects.The schoolrsquos Eco teacher, Mrs Bronagh Reid, said the school was delighted to welcome Matthew back.ldquoHe was very friendly to all the pupils, who found him very inspiring, said Mrs Reid. ldquoIt was good that he called with us on a day off and it was down to his mother Margaret, who sits on our board of governors.ldquoWe were all hoping that Matthew would make into the final but very impressed that he cog to the semi-final.The schoolrsquos cash injection is part of the Rural Community Pollinator Grants Scheme, which is financed by the Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairsand managed by the civic-pride campaign, Live Here Love Here.It is designed to allow community groups and schools across rural Northern Ireland to benefit from funding between pound, to pound, to establish, enhance or develop a local community pollinator garden.A pollinator garden is a shared space with pollinating plants, habitats, wildflowers, flowers, shrubs and trees, and the grants support new initiatives aimed at protecting and providing for pollinators.Mrs Sarah McDowell, principal, said: ldquoWe plan to use the money to create an outdoor learning space which will enhance our school grounds and the local community.ldquoWe will build an outdoor classroom and plant fruit trees to attract more wildle to our school grounds.`We are delighted to receive the support of Live Here Love Here to help us create this space which will benefit the children in our school and will help to improve bioersity in the area.She added: ldquoWe look forward to starting to create this area after Christmas and have it ready for the spring term.The pilot scheme, which made pound. million available for  , aims to cover % of costs to community groups and schools wishing to embark on the community environmental project.Successful grant applicants were required to illustrate their plans to maximise pollinator-friendly land-management techniques to increase the bioersity value of an area by planting for pollinators, and to transform unused spaces into valued community spaces, adding habitats and greening-up formerly grey areas..prettyPhoto

title: Students involved in All Island lights switch off climate event
story: THE lights went out at Stormont at the weekend thanks to ecologically aware local high school studentsA group of pupils from St Patrickrsquos Grammar School and Down High School, who are involved in the All-Island Schools  Climate Action programme, asked for the lights at Stormont to be switched off for one hour on Saturday evening.Local MLAs Harry Harvey and Colin McGrath helped ensure that the request was fast-tracked, with Mr Harveyrsquos we, Sharon, doing a lot of the work behind the scenes.Mr Harvey met with staff and pupils from the two schools in the grounds of Parliament Buildings to observe the dimming of the lights.Stormont joined in solidarity with the  countries from around the world that participated in the th anniversary of the global Earth Hour. Public buildings are often lit up in dferent colours to express support for a particular cause.The floodlights that illuminate several public buildings in Downpatrick, including Down Cathedral and St Patrickrsquos Church, were also turned off. Pupils from both schools took part in a Downpatrick community litter pick, filling a largetrailer with the refuse that was collected, and were joined by local councillors Oonagh Hanlon and Alan Lewis.The pupils then observed the Downpatrick switch-off from the vantage point of Gallows Hill, and enjoyed an open-air concert with vocals supplied by Eva Rowan, from St Patrickrsquos Grammar School who was the winner of the BBC NI Secondary School Soloist of the Year competition.Down High and St Patrickrsquos both have active Eco-committees and the schools hope to continue to work with Newry, Mourne and Down Council in identying and cultivating community growing areas.St Patrickrsquos Grammar School and Down High School are delighted to be able toto face-to-face collaborations, as lockdown restrictions are relaxed.Last week, pupils attended a conference at Titanic Belfast and heard some inspirational presentations from former Northern Ireland soccer star Gerry Armstrong and Richard Maguire, from East Belfast GAA club.This week, some artists from the two schools will be involved in shared art workshops in The Hans Sloane Centre in Killyleagh..prettyPhoto

title: Three centuries of worship marked with anniversary service in Seaforde
story: A LONG-AWAITED celebration took place in Loughinisland Parish Church, Seaforde, last Thursday mdash St Macartanrsquos Day mdash when the parish andcommunity came together to celebrate over  years of worship in the building.The tercentenary celebration year was to be , and a number of events were organised, but the Covid pandemic meant that all but one had to be cancelled.It was with genuine joy and relief that people joined together for a much anticipated service at which two magnicent mosaics created by artist and parishioner Maeve King were dedicated.The mosaics were dedicated by the Bishop of Down and Dromore, the Right Rev David McClay, and the preacher was the Archbishop of Armagh, the Most Rev John McDowell.Archbishop McDowell looked into the history of the parish in his sermon and encouraged the congregation to continue trusting in God for the future.Both he and Bishop McClay conveyed their gratitude to the Select Vestry and generations of worshippers for their stewardship of the church over the centuries.The service was introduced by the Dean of Down and Rector of the Lecale Area Mission Partnership , the Very Rev Henry Hull. Parish Reader Lucy Cullen led the service alongside Bishop McClay. Father Ciaraacuten Dallat, Parish Priest of St Macartanrsquos, Loughinisland, read the gospel and representatives of other local churches were also present.The two mosaics feature an image of the Lamb of God atop the world and the dove of the Holy Spirit descending from heaven, both of whose halos contain  carat gold leaf covered by a thin hand blown layer of crystal.Artist Maeve King spoke of the atmosphere of serenity this project afforded as she worked on the pieces during the pandemic.The service also featured the premier of a short setting of the Angus Dei composed by Maeve Kingrsquos cousin, Jason McKinstry, and inspired by her mosaics. Mathew Forde, from Seaforde, wrote a potted history of the parish for inclusion in the order of service and read a lesson.Speaking after the service, the Rev Adrian Dorrian, Vicar of LAMP with responsibility for Seaforde, said: ldquoIt is a true blessing, after over two years of delayed plans, to have been able to come together to celebrate three centuries of worship in the Church here in Seaforde, although Loughinisland Parish has an even longer history.ldquoWe were able to look back with thanksgiving mdash some of the communion plate used during the service dates from its opening  years ago mdash and look forward with hope and confidence by dedicating these stunning mosaics to the glory of God and pray that they will bless people in future generations.Mr Dorrian added: ldquoAcross over  years of Godrsquos people worshipping in this place, and especially during the past two years of pandemic, he has been faithful. We have so much for which to be thankful here, and I hope our celebration will set the tone for our worship and thanksgiving in the days and years to come..prettyPhoto

title: Tourism centre closure blasted
story: THE closure of a dedicated tourism information centre in Downpatrick has been heavily criticised by two politicians.Cllrs Cadogan Enright and Patrick Brown have also criticised their Newry, Mourne and Down Council colleagues for agreeing to the closure of the tourist information centre housed within the St Patrick Centre.The role of the two council staff who manned the tourist information centre will now be handled by St Patrick Centre employees.Cllr Enright is also concerned that a proposal he tabled at a recent council meeting for the issue to be further discussed was rejected.ldquoTo suggest that the Saint Patrickrsquos Centre can somehow pick up the slack on its diminished funding makes no sense, he declared. ldquoWe need a full time tourism office working seven days a week in Downpatrick.Cllr Enright said the local authority runs tourism information centres in Newcastle, Kilkeel, Newry and CrossmaglenHe insisted that the Downpatrick area, regarded by many as the jewel in the local councilrsquos tourism crown, cannot become an afterthought when it comes to tourism promotion.Cllr Brown said he was ldquomost disturbed by the development, which ldquoworryingly follows on the back of the scaling-down of the Down County Museum.He continued: ldquoIt is unreasonable for Newry, Mourne and Down Council to expect the Saint Patrick Centre to pick up the slack from the loss of these two tourism staff with no increase in funding, he continued.ldquoFunding for the Centre was slashed from pound, per annum to pound, per annum  years ago, with the local council paying pound, in rent for the tourism centre located in the building.ldquoThis means that the Centre has had to manage on pound, per annum with no inflation adjustment for over  years and now must cover the work of two full-time council staff.He added: ldquoNo matter what way the issue is spun, it is about a net cut in essential frontline tourism services which are key to tourism growth and economic development in this area.ldquoWhile I am aware of the huge amount of voluntary work and fundraising that goes on at the Saint Patrick Centre, to suggest that it can easily take up the slack for two full-time council staff looks very improbable to me.ldquoThese two posts were redeployed during Covid- and I want them reinstated..prettyPhoto

story: No united Ireland for generations to come, insists Doug Beattie as UUP launch election manesto   RALLY BREAKDOWN: All the upcoming parades and protests against the Northern Ireland Brexit ProtocolNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisUkraineSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes  Gardense-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionBelfast’s maritime heritage is a source of pride - and hopeNews Letter editorial on Friday April  :By EditorialFriday, st April , : pm  "       "  News Letter editorialThe Ulster Unionist Party launched its Assembly  election manesto beside HMS Caroline at Alexandra Dock on Belfast Lough yesterday.The last surviving warship from the Battle of Jutland during World War One had its future secured recently with a fresh injection of cash from many quarters including the National Heritage Lottery Fund.It is a floating monument and a source of pride in the maritime history of Belfast and Northern Ireland as a whole especially when one considers that  Irishmen from every tradition on this island fought and died during that momentous sea battle. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.At the same time the UUP candidates gathered at HMS Caroline nearby Titanic Belfast was celebrating its th birthday and over that decade it has welcomed over six million visitors from more than  countries. It has also generated an estimated £ million for the Northern Ireland Economy in that period.By a benign coincidence it was announced on Thursday that this summer a record  cruise ships will dock in Belfast bringing a much welcomed post-Covid wave of mass tourist spending across the Province.The waters through which the Titanic was launched and that HMS Caroline sped through to fight that decisive naval battle were in the th century the pathway circuits by which Belfast’s industrial revolution was turbocharged. In the st century these circuits are flowing back in the opposite direction, pulling millions upon millions of tourist-driven pounds into Northern Ireland’s economic heart, boosting expenditure and creating jobs after the devastation of the Pandemic. The city’s sea faring tradition both naval and merchant over the centuries is not only one to be proud of but also to take hope from. Belfast rose up around its lough and the Lagan. story: Major development in Roy Reynolds murder investigation   Ramadan : What is Ramadan  Ramadan dates  - and how to wish someone a happy RamadanNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisUkraineSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes  Gardense-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionBen Lowry: Three things to watch out for in the coming Stormont electionThe Stormont election is little more than a month away, on Thursday May .By Ben LowrySaturday, nd April , : am  "       "  Will unionists get a combined vote share in the high s percentage,, as in - Stormont elections, or will they be down at %, as in  Westminster There are three key things to watch out for.l The first is the extent to which the campaign and results are influenced by the most obvious and important issue in the contest — the Northern Ireland ProtocolThere is no shortage of pundits who will say that the voters care more about issues such as health. But when it comes to casting their ballots, up to % of people who go have hitherto gone to the polls in NI elections have voted for political parties who are primarily identied by their stance on the constitutional question.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.Even in recent elections the non-aligned centre ground, despite having surged , are doing well to get more than % of the votes.Do not be fooled by anyone who says that the protocol is only of importance to unionists, and that even many unionists do not care. Many of the people who make this point themselves care very much about the Irish Sea border — they want to keep it, either because they support staying in the EU , or because they see it as major step towards an economic united Ireland, and thus towards a more general all-Ireland.It is true that many of the more apolitical unionists are much more relaxed about the protocol than they should be, but that is typically because it is complex .It is also because such unionists heard that the protocol offered the best of both worlds .Thus unionists should have been, and should still be, trying to explain and reiterate to some of the more apathetic pro Union voters the ultimate impact of the NI Protocol. This would entail trying to revive some of the spirit of indignation that there was in the early months of , when many people across the Province were suddenly finding that they could not get deliveries from Great Britain that they had always been able to get before.The EU has been keen to agree to case-by-case exemptions to checks in part because it does not want the wider public to be troubled by the protocol. Needless to say, therefore, unionists badly need to see a large vote for parties that oppose the protocol.Doug Beattie’s approach to the Irish Sea border, of opposing it but calling for engagement in the pursuit of political solutions to the problems that it creates, has a high-wire quality. If the Alliance vote goes down, even slightly, on recent elections, and the Ulster Unionist Party vote increases, Mr Beattie will be able to say that his tactics have stemmed the decline of unionism by broadening its appeal.If Alliance continues upwards, and the UUP does not rise, he will be seen to have not only been weak on the protocol, but having failed to win over moderates in the process.l The second key thing to watch out for in the election is turnoutThere was a time in the s and early s when it seemed voters in the western world were losing interest in politics.Countries such as the UK and United States were increasingly wealthy and many bitter political disagreements of the s and s seemed to give way to a more bland, moderate politics. In Northern Ireland itself, this wider trend towards consensus seemed to be reflected in the  Belfast Agreement. But this sense of stable politics has evaporated, at home and abroad. There are now bitter ides on major issues of national and global importance, and much turbulence in voting patterns.The Brexit referendum of  had a higher turnoutthan most recent UK general elections have done.The Scottish independence plebiscite in  had an even higher turnout .The fiercely contested, and narrowly decided, US presidential election between Donald Trump and Joe Biden in November  had one of the highest turnouts of any presidential race in modern memory .In Northern Ireland, the turnout surged from % of voters in the  Stormont election to % a year later, in the more fraught atmosphere of the election after Sinn Fein collapsed the institutions.There is now keen interest in conflicts and politics at home and abroad. Before Russia invaded Ukraine, I feared people in the UK would not care much, seeing it as a distant problem. I was relieved to be proven wrong by the massive interest there was in such a serious global matter.A high turnout next month would show that the population in NI still think that Stormont and issues such as the protocol matter.l The final thing to watch is the vote shares of the two communitiesWill it be like the  general election, when the DUP and Sinn Fein dominated thingsor like  when they plunged to a combined % Will unionists get a combined vote share in the high s %, as in the  and  Stormont elections, or will they be down round %, as in  Westminster  Will nationalists combined get more than % of the vote, as they have done in some elections, or go back under that level It will be a bad day indeed for unionismthe combined vote is as low as %, as some polls have suggested, or even in the high s.ProtocolNorthern IrelandDoug BeattieBen LowryIrish Sea  "       "  Get the latest news on the CoronavirusWe have launched a daily public interest bulletin to deliver all the updates and vital information to your inboxSign Up  Most PopularRamadan : What is Ramadan  Ramadan dates  - story: DUP’s Gordon Lyons: Sinn Fein election rally a show of strength for border poll   Ramadan : What is Ramadan  Ramadan dates  - and how to wish someone a happy RamadanNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisUkraineSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes  Gardense-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsPoliticsFree Covid tests end in England today - here is the situation in Northern IrelandFree Covid tests end in England today - but free tests will continue in Northern Ireland subject to certain conditions.By Philip BradfieldFriday, st April , : pm  "       "  Free Covid tests end in England today - but free tests will continue in Northern Ireland subject to certain conditions.Free universal testing for the virus ends in England today, Thursday, despite concerns that Covid rates are still high there.From  April, most people in England will have to pay for a lateral flow test and high street pharmacies there are charging about £ per test. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.Provision of Covid tests by government are changing.However free testing will persist in NI for some time yet subject, to some changes. Stormont Health Minister Robin Swann says that testing will continue to play a vital role in Northern Ireland’s response to COVID- over the coming months but that a “more targeted approach” will be introduced on a phased basis from April, with the focus on supporting and protecting those at highest risk of serious illness.Under the new policy, PCR testing in NI will cease for most people with symptoms from  April - however free lateral flow tests will continue to be available to the public to use should they develop Covid symptoms.Lateral flow tests will also continue to be available free of charge to support those living in, working in or visiting a higher risk setting, such as a care home, until the end of June, with a further review then.The policy covers testing and contact tracing and takes effect from  April. No changes will be introduced in Northern Ireland until that date. The policy will be kept under review during the period of transition up until the end of June.The full range of changes to take effect from  April in Northern Ireland are as follows-* PCR testing will no longer be recommended or available for most people with symptoms. It will still be available to support the small group for whom it is recommended for clinical reasons. The PCR home ordering service will remain available for the general public to support those for whom PCR is recommended.* Publicly accessible COVID- testing sites will close. Local Health and Social Care Trusts will continue to provide PCR testing to support clinical care.* Those with symptoms will be advised to use lateral flow devicesto test instead of booking a PCR. This will be kept under review and could remain in place up to the end of June depending on disease trajectory.* Routine asymptomatic testing - testing for those with no symptoms - will continue to be advised for those living, working and visiting health and social care settings including hospitals and care homes and other high risk settings in line with public health advice. This will be kept under review.* Asymptomatic LFD testing for the wider population will cease. Access to free LFDs for this purpose will cease.* Routine asymptomatic workplace testing will cease.* Routine asymptomatic testing in most educational settingswill cease at the Easter break.* Asymptomatic testing in special schools will continue after Easter and will be kept under review. It may continue until the end of June .* Routine population contact tracing will be phased out between mid-April and the end of June.Chief Medical Officer Professor Sir Michael McBride said: “We will continue throughout the transition phase to support and protect our most vulnerable. After these changes are introduced from  April, I would urge people to check on NI Directtesting remains recommended for them - for examplethey are eligible for new treatments. In the coming weeks, the Department will also be working to provide advice and support to those eligible for treatments. It is particularly important that those who are at higher risk of serious illness follow the guidance on getting tested.”The Chief Medical Officer added: “The tools at our disposal to protect people who are at higher risk from COVID- have advanced considerably since the early days of the pandemic. Alongside the vaccine and booster programme, new COVID- treatments continue to be used by patients in Northern Ireland and new treatments are in development.“As the amount of testing across society reduces, our behaviour and actions have an even more important role in preventing transmission and keeping others safe. I urge everyone to continue to follow the public health guidance including continuing to wear a face covering in enclosed settings like public transport and when visiting hospitals and care homes.”The changes do not take effect until  April, and current testing provision will continue until then.A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: barry penarth residents school holidays shortened
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityWe asked the people of Barry and Penarth on their thoughts of the reduction of the summer school holidays from six weeks to three, which could come in under plans to modernise the academic year.The Welsh Government has not said anything on when or how any changes could or would be introduced but it has been greeted with a mixed reaction.Sarah Timmins said: “Don’t confuse school with childcare. Continue with six weeks holiday in the summer at least! We get the shortest summer break in the world. State should provide free affordable childcare.”Trena Wise said: “Four weeks would be better and spread the rest throughout the year.” This was agreed with by Lisa Gerrard.Trudi Thomas said: “Five weeks and an extra week off at Christmas.”Iulia Condurache said: “These kids need this. Where is this obsession to work more is coming from  School is enough, work week is too much. Cut the bloody huge pays, tax the rich properly, educate for sustainability not waste and you will have a balance.”MORE NEWS:Kelly Crowther said: “No. By moving the extra leave to October and December is going to cost me so much more to entertain the kids. At least in the summer we can hopefully enjoy the sunshine and free stuff as parks and beaches.”Lynne Bryan said: “Yes definitely they get to many holidays as it is.”Luna Davies said: “Perhaps four weeks but the last week of school is turned over to fun activities without academic focus. Add the other week in to Christmas. If it comes after Christmas, the kids should have enough to do to entertain themselves.”Paula Chapman said: “Id rather four weeks to be honest. And let the kids have an extra week at Christmas and Easter. Six weeks is just a bit long by week four they are usually bored and craving a bit of normality and routine.”.removeMike Corbridge said: “No... probably parents wish it was shorter. I had six when I was a kid and it wasnt long enough.”Tracy Lewis said: “Yes.... six weeksis way too long. title: mobile network upgrade might cause tv signal issues
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe upgrades to the mobile networks may interfere with televisions that receive signals through an aerial, such as Freeview, BT, TalkTalk and YouView.Potential issues may range from intermittent sound, to pixellation problems, to a complete loss of signal.Restore TV are offering free support to anyone who may be affected by the issues.Restore TV is run by an organisation called Digital Mobile Spectrum Limitedwhich is owned by EE, Virgin Media O, Three and Vodafone.Their role is to ensure that people can still watch free to view TVmobile service upgrades cause TV interference.:Ben Roome, CEO of Restore TV, said: "We know just how important TV is to inform, entertain and provide welcome company."Restore TV exists to ensure we all can continue to access free to view TV as mobile services are improved across the country.”"If you see new TV interference, we’re on hand to help you resolve the issue. We can send a Restore TV filter, free of charge, for you to fit between your aerial lead and TV or set-top box to remove mobile signals and allow you to watch free to view TV as normal."Full instructions are included, and we can provide further advice online and by phoneneeded."In most instances, fitting the filter will resolve any issues, butthis isn’t the case, we may also be able to arrange a follow-up visit from a Restore TV engineer at no cost, depending on eligibility."Cable and satellite TV, such as Sky or Virgin, are not affected, but viewers with these services who also watch free to view TV through an aerial can receive a free Restore TV filter..removeViewers who receive interference on their TV should call the free number     or visit the Restore TV website

title: woman completes half marathon mha penarth communities
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityRoxy Pollard, , who lives in Cornwall, took up running in  and recently embarked on her first half marathon – raising £ for MHA Penarth Communities, a Methodist Homes Association charity that offers events and outings for older people in the area.She took up running in  and ran , miles to raise £, for charity. After smashing this target, she wanted to raise more.Ms Pollard trained hard for weeks and finally plucked up the courage to run in the Newport Half Marathon on March .“I ran for four to six hours every week to prepare myself,” she said.“It was tough going and I wasnt aiming to be among the leaders.“I finished in just under three hours, which was the target I set myself."MDA Penarth Communities is one of dozens of branches in the UK, with each bringing people aged over  together for activities.Penarth MHA Communities group, based in Trinity Methodist Church community hall, raises funds to offers regular activities for its members living in Penarth, Llandough and Sully.Penarth manager, Linda Brownhill, said: “Roxy and I met at national MHA conferences, when she was the local manager for the Cornwall group. We became firm friends and I’m thrilled that she came here to raise money for us.“We got up early to cheer her on in the half marathon and we were there when she finished. She is amazing.”The Penarth group is always keen to welcome new members.They currently meet every Friday for coffee, lunch club and afternoon activities. Plus on Wednesdays they head out on minibuses, visiting venues all over the Vale of Glamorgan.Anyone interested in joining the group - as a member, or as a volunteer - can call Lina Brownhill on .The group meets in Trinity Church, Woodland Place, Penarth CF EX. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log Share s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"  CommentsComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: amazon workers nyc vote unionise
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityWarehouse workers cast , votes — or about % — in favour of a union, giving the fledgling Amazon Labor Union enough support to pull off a victory.According to the National Labor Relations Board, which is overseeing the process, , workers — or % — rejected the union bid.The  ballots that were challenged by either Amazon or the ALU were not enough to sway the outcome. Federal labour officials said the results of the count will not be veried until they process any objections — due by April  — that both parties may file.Chris Smalls, a fired Amazon employee who has been leading the ALU in its fight on Staten Island, emerged from the NLRB building in Brooklyn on Friday with other union organisers, pumping their fists and jumping, chanting “ALU”.“I hope that everybody’s paying attention now because a lot of people doubted us,” he said.Mr Smalls hopes the success in New York will embolden workers at other facilities to launch their own organising campaigns. Even his group will soon sht their attention to a neighbouring Amazon warehouse on Staten Island, where a separate union election is scheduled to be held in late April.Amazon posted a statement on its company website on Friday saying that it was evaluating its options following the election.“We’re disappointed with the outcome of the election in Staten Island because we believe having a direct relationship with the company is best for our employees,” the post said.“We’re evaluating our options, including filing objections based on the inappropriate and undue influence by the NLRB that we and otherswitnessed in this election.”The company did not elaborate but it signalled it might challenge the election based on a lawsuit filed in March by the NLRB, which sought to force Amazon to reinstate a fired employee who was involved in the union drive..remove vw,vw,px, px"The successful union effort on Staten Island stood in contrast to the one launched in Bessemer, Alabama NLRB spokesperson Kayla Blado responded to Amazon’s statement by noting that the independent agency has been authorised by Congress to enforce the National Labour Relations Act.“All NLRB enforcement actions against Amazon have been consistent with that Congressional mandate,” she said.The successful union effort on Staten Island stood in contrast to the one launched in Bessemer, Alabama by the more established Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union.Workers at an Amazon warehouse there appeared to have rejected a union bid but outstanding challenged ballots could change the outcome. The votes were -to- against the union. A hearing to review  challenged ballots is expected to begin in the next few days.Amazon has long been considered a top prize for the labour movement given the company’s massive size and impact.
